The Code of Music

This course explores music through the lenses of computation and interactivity.

The first part of the semester is a structured exploration of rhythm, melody, timbre, and harmony. We will look into each of these elements from the standpoint of music, code, and design: each class, we will listen to examples from different periods and styles, manipulate the element programmaticaly, and create an interactive study around it.

During the second half of the semester we will cover algorithmic composition techniques such as Markov Chains, Neural Networks and L-systems. As students work toward their final projects, the class takes on a more self-directed approach. Final projects might be digital applications, spatial installations, or physical devices.

In-class coding and exercises will be done in P5.js, but students will be free to use other languages and frameworks for their final projects. ICM or equivalent programming experience is required.

Midterm Project
Create an interactive or generative musical experience focusing on one musical element. Your project can be either a new concept or an extension/refinement of an earlier assignment.

Final Project
Create an interactive musical piece. It can live in the browser, a physical device, or in space. In your presentation, discuss musical, design, and programming aspects of your project.

This syllabus will be updated weekly with code, links and notes.

Part I: the elements

Rhythm

Class Meeting

Beats, tempo, subdivision, accents, syncopation, polyrhythm

Code:

  • Time: draw loop >> sound loop
  • Create a sequencer. Durations.
  • Variations over time: probability, interactivity

Interact & Discuss: Groove Pizza

Design: Sketch two different interfaces to explore rhythm

Assignments

Focusing on one or more of the concepts covered in class, create an interactive piece that explores rhythm. Post the working sketch and a recording of a 20-second performance of it to your blog.

Melody

Class Meeting

Pitches, intervals, scales

Code:

  • Note representation: frequencies and MIDI
  • Play a score
  • Arithmetics: notes, intervals and scales
  • Modify your sequencer to include pitch

Interact & Discuss: Song Maker

Design: Sketch an interactive piece that focuses on melody.

Assignments

Create a melody-driven interactive piece. Record a 20-second composition using it. Post both to your blog.

Part II: complex methods

In the second part of the course we will cover algorithmic techniques to generate music including Markov Chains, L-Systems, and Neural Networks. As students work toward their final projects, contents will adapt to the group's needs and interests.
